com.google.appinventor.client.editor.simple.components
Class MockComponent

java.lang.Object
  com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.UIObject
      com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Widget
          com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Composite
              com.google.appinventor.client.editor.simple.components.MockComponent
All Implemented Interfaces:
DragSource, PropertyChangeListener, HasAttachHandlers, HasHandlers, EventListener, IsWidget, SourcesMouseEvents
Direct Known Subclasses:
MockNonVisibleComponent, MockVisibleComponent
public abstract class MockComponent
extends Composite
implements PropertyChangeListener, SourcesMouseEvents, DragSource

Abstract superclass for all components in the visual designer.

Since the actual component implementation are for a target platform that is different from the platform used to implement the development environment, we need to mock them.

Author:
lizlooney@google.com (Liz Looney)

onCreateFromPalette

public void onCreateFromPalette()
Invoked after a component is created from the palette.

Some subclasses may wish to override this method to initialize properties of the newly created component. For example, a component with a caption may want to initialize the caption to match the component's name.

The returned list should not be modified.

onSelectedChange

protected void onSelectedChange(boolean selected)
Invoked when the selection state of this component changes.

Implementations may override this method to perform additional alterations to their appearance based on their new selection state. Overriders must call super.onSelectedChange(selected) before performing their own alterations.

onDragStart in interface DragSource

createDragWidget

public final Widget createDragWidget(int x,
                                     int y)
Description copied from interface: DragSource
Returns a new widget that will be shown while a drag is in progress.

This widget is owned by the caller and the callee should not modify it or embed it anywhere else in the UI.

The widget will be positioned relative to the cursor based on its CSS positional attributes. For example, if the returned widget has the properties position: absolute; left: 5px; top: 10px, the widget will be positioned so that the hot spot of the cursor is 5px to the left of and 10px to the top of the top-left corner of the widget. It is recommended that implementors use the DragSourceSupport.configureDragWidgetToAppearWithCursorAt(Widget, int, int) method to configure where the widget will appear relative to the cursor.

This will be called once for every start of a drag gesture.

Specified by:
createDragWidget in interface DragSource
Parameters:
x - the x position of the cursor in the drag source's coordinate system where the mouse-down event that initiated the drag occurred; not necessarily the same as the current location of the cursor
y - the y position of the cursor in the drag source's coordinate system where the mouse-down event that initiated the drag occurred; not necessarily the same as the current location of the cursor
Returns:
widget to be shown while dragging; owned by the caller

getDragWidget

public Widget getDragWidget()
Description copied from interface: DragSource
Returns the widget that is being dragged.

Specified by:
getDragWidget in interface DragSource

getDropTargets

public DropTarget[] getDropTargets()
Description copied from interface: DragSource
Returns all possible drop targets for this drag source.

The returned targets will be checked in order to determine a valid drop target; therefore the order of the returned targets is significant if multiple targets overlap. In particular, overlapping sets of targets must be specified in depth first order.

This will be called once for every start of a drag gesture.

Specified by:
getDropTargets in interface DragSource
Returns:
array of drop targets

onDragEnd

public final void onDragEnd()
Description copied from interface: DragSource
Invoked when a drag-gesture has ended, regardless of whether a drop actually occurred.

If a drop has actually occurred and DropTarget.onDrop(DragSource, int, int, int, int) is called, the invocation of this method will immediately follow it.

Specified by:
onDragEnd in interface DragSource

getPreferredWidth

public int getPreferredWidth()
Returns the preferred width of the component if there was no layout restriction, including the CSS border.

Callers should be aware that most components cannot calculate their preferred size correctly until they are attached to the UI; see Composite.isAttached(). Unattached components are liable to return 0 for any query about their preferred size.

Returns:
preferred width

getPreferredHeight

public int getPreferredHeight()
Returns the preferred height of the component if there was no layout restriction, including the CSS border.

Callers should be aware that most components cannot calculate their preferred size correctly until they are attached to the UI; see Composite.isAttached(). Unattached components are liable to return 0 for any query about their preferred size.

Returns:
preferred height
